climbs.name: The Ice Funnel
climbs.fa: Frank Campbell and Dave Dance, Jan. 1987

content.description:
The Ice Funnel is a fantastic, seldom climbed line. 

P1 (60m): From the base climb 20 meters of WI2-3 ice onto some snow for another 20 meters. Work your way to the base of the steep pillar. Either belay your second here or continue up the pillar (WI4 crux) for another 20 meters and set up a belay.

P2 (65m): Climb up a narrow "funnel" of WI3 for 30 meters, you will see a bolted station to your left (note location for your rappel), continue past it up another wide step of ice and build a belay.

P3 (25m): Climb up the final wide curtain of WI3-4 ice to a bolted belay on the left side.

Descent: Rap from bolts at the top of P3 to bolts halfway through P2. From there rap to a V thread at the top of the pillar (70s won't make it to the bottom) and then one final rap to the ground.

From the parking area, follow the cutline West/Southwest to it's end at the mouth of the drainage. From the end of the cutline cut left and down into the creekbed. The Ice Funnel should be obvious on the south facing cliffs ahead. Work your way across the slopes to the base. 2-4 hours from the car depending on how much snow there is.
Standard ice rack.

climbs.name: Kemosabe
climbs.fa: Frank Campbell and Dave Dancer,  Jan. 1987

content.description:
Kemosabe is a great climb in a spectacular but committing setting. Originally graded WI4 by Frank Campbell on the first ascent in 1987, it is notorious for being significantly harder than anything that could be reasonably called WI4. To reflect this and bring it in line with climbs of similar difficulty (as well as personal experience on this climb and other WI5 routes) I have put a difficulty rating of WI5 on this entry. Note that the best time to climb Kemosabe in years where ice conditions are average is January/February. Earlier in the season it can be chandeliered, wet and largely unprotectable and later in the season the first pitch will generally melt out.   Pitch 1 (50m) - Climb WI3/4 ice for 40 meters through a pinch in the rock where the ice can narrow to less than a meter in width. Build an ice belay where comfortable, bring up your partners and then walk into the amphitheater. Pitch 2 (60m) -  Climb the rambling ice to the crux pillar and fire up vertical, mushroomed and aerated ice which can be hard to protect at time. Build an ice belay at the top. Rappel from v threads. From the parking area follow the cut line West to its end and then drop down into the trees working your way West and gaining elevation until you are on a broad open scree hill/snow slope.

Traverse the snow slope and Kemosabe will come into view on your right. Drop down into the drainage to the base of pitch 1.

1 to 2 hours depending on conditions. Standard ice rack.

Waiporous Creek is an incredibly remote area North of the Ghost, encompassing a good number of seldom climbed ice climbs and huge potential for new rock routes in a spectacular setting. The only downsides are access is fairly arduous, requires a beast of a 4x4 vehicle and even then approaches to climbs are long. For those willing to commit to getting out here however, the climbs are well worth it and you don't have to worry about getting scooped or seeing another soul around.
